abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector Project
            for Ghana were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            demand-driven competitive funding mechanism is an effective
            instrument for allocating public funding aimed at fostering
            innovation, relevance and quality in tertiary education as
            long as the selection criteria are clear, transparent, and
            well publicized. The efficient and timely implementation of
            project activities is contingent upon building and
            sustaining project implementation capacity. Funds
            administered against agreed district plans encourages
            pooling of funds and can be the basis for improving the
            effective targeting of resources to meet the specific needs
            of districts. Pilot programs must establish sound monitoring
            and evaluation systems to measure impact, identify problems
            and take corrective measures. Overly ambitious sector-wide
            reforms take time to prepare, own and implement and cannot
            be undertaken in a Specific Investment Loan (SIL)
            particularly when there is limited institutional capacity.
